sections.title: Local Self-Government-Rural
sections.content_md: In India, there is a three-tier system of government. The **Central Government** looks after the interests of the whole country, while **State Governments** manage State administration. At the local level, **Local Self-Government** manages local affairs through the representatives of the locality, forming an integral part of this system.

sections.title: Rural: Three-tier system of Panchayati Raj- Gram Panchayat, Panchayat Samiti, Zila Parishad - their meaning and functions.
sections.content_md:
The system of Local Self-Government in rural areas is known as the **Panchayati Raj**. It is a three-tier system consisting of:
1.  **Gram Panchayat** at the village level.
2.  **Panchayat Samiti** at the block level.
3.  **Zila Parishad** at the district level.

These bodies are responsible for local administration and development, managing their affairs through elected representatives.

sections.title: MEANING OF LOCAL SELF-GOVERNMENT
sections.content_md: **Local self-government** is an institution comprising locally elected representatives managing the affairs of the locality and providing them with basic amenities. In a rural area, such an institution is called **Panchayat**, and in an urban area, it is known as a **Municipal Corporation** or **Municipality**.

sections.title: LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND LOCAL SELF-GOVERNMENT
sections.content_md:
**Local self-government** is distinct from **local government**. 

In **local government**, the administration of a locality is managed by officials appointed by the State. These officials, such as a **patwari**, policeman, or village chowkidar, are paid a salary and provide services but have no say in the management of local affairs.

**Local self-government** consists of elected representatives. They receive government grants for activities like sanitation, providing elementary education, and settling disputes. This means that local people govern themselves.

sections.title: SIGNIFICANCE OF LOCAL SELF-GOVERNMENT
sections.content_md: The local self-government institutions play an important role in the functioning of democracy at the grassroot level. This importance also stresses the need for having such institutions.

sections.title: (i) These institutions provide the foundations on which the entire democratic structure of our country stands. These institutions make it possible for local people to take interest in their own affairs and groom them well to take on larger responsibilities later.
sections.content_md: These institutions form the foundation of India's democratic structure. They encourage local people to participate in their own affairs, preparing them for larger responsibilities in the future.

sections.title: (ii) The local institutions provide a training ground for local leadership and to gain necessary experience for undertaking bigger challenges at the state or the national level.
sections.content_md: Local institutions serve as a training ground for local leaders, allowing them to gain the experience needed for bigger roles at the state or national level.

sections.title: (iii) Local people know their problems well and are best judges of their own needs.
sections.content_md: Local people have the best understanding of their own problems and needs, making them the most suitable judges for local matters.

sections.title: (iv) The local institutions encourage self-help and voluntary service and save the state of many unnecessary expenses.
sections.content_md: These institutions promote self-help and voluntary service, which helps save the state from unnecessary expenses.

sections.title: (v) Lodal self-government institutions gain the support of local communities.
sections.content_md: Local self-government institutions are effective because they gain the support of the local communities they serve.

sections.title: (vi) Through these institutions government can reach ordinary citizens in times of need like National Emergency.
sections.content_md: These institutions enable the government to reach ordinary citizens effectively during times of need, such as a National Emergency.

sections.title: (vii) These institutions lessen the burden of workload on State and Central Government machinery.
sections.content_md: By managing local affairs, these institutions reduce the workload of the State and Central Government machinery.

sections.title: (viii) They facilitate active participation of local people as an individual can evaluate the performance of the elected representatives.
sections.content_md: They encourage active participation from local people, who can directly evaluate the performance of their elected representatives.

sections.title: SALIENT FEATURES OF THE CONSTITUTION (73RD AMENDMENT) ACT, 1992
sections.content_md: The **Panchayati Raj** system was first inaugurated at Nagaur in Rajasthan on October 2, 1959. A significant development was the **Constitution (73rd Amendment) Act, 1992**, which came into force on April 24, 1993. This date is celebrated as **National Panchayati Raj Diwas** annually. The salient features of this Act are:

sections.title: (i) To provide three-tier system of Panchayati Raj for all States having population of over 20 lakh,
sections.content_md: The Act mandates a **three-tier system of Panchayati Raj** for all states with a population exceeding 20 lakh.

sections.title: (ii) To hold Panchayat elections regularly every five years,
sections.content_md: It ensures that **Panchayat elections** are held regularly every five years.

sections.title: (iii) To provide reservation of seats for Scheduled Castes, Scheduled Tribes and women.
sections.content_md: The Act provides for the **reservation of seats** for Scheduled Castes, Scheduled Tribes, and women in Panchayats.

sections.title: (iv) To constitute State Finance Commissions every five years to make recommendations on financial powers of the Panchayats,
sections.content_md: It requires the constitution of a **State Finance Commission** every five years to review the financial position of the Panchayats and make recommendations.

sections.title: (v) To constitute District Planning Committee to prepare draft development plan for the district as a whole.
sections.content_md: It provides for the constitution of a **District Planning Committee** to prepare a draft development plan for the entire district.

sections.title: PANCHAYATI RAJ SYSTEM
sections.content_md: A three-tier system of Local Self-Government for rural areas came into effect in April 1993. It includes Panchayats at the village level, Block Samitis at the block level, and District Boards (Zila Parishad) at the apex. The nomenclature varies between states, but the basic structure is a three-tier system with the village at the base, the Panchayat Samiti at the block level, and the Zila Parishad at the district level.

sections.title: ORGANISATION OF PANCHAYATI RAJ INSTITUTION
sections.content_md: The three-tier system comprises the following:

sections.title: (i) Gram Panchayats at village level.
sections.content_md: **Gram Panchayats** at the village level.

sections.title: (ii) Panchayat Samiti at block level or middle level.
sections.content_md: **Panchayat Samiti** at the block or middle level.

sections.title: (iii) Zila Parishad at District level.
sections.content_md: **Zila Parishad** at the District level.

sections.title: In addition, a Nyaya Panchayat has been provided for every three or four village Panchayats.
sections.content_md: In addition, a **Nyaya Panchayat** has been provided for every three or four village Panchayats to handle judicial functions.

sections.title: (a) Qualification for Election to Local Bodies
sections.content_md: A candidate seeking election to any of the local bodies must have the following qualifications:

sections.title: (i) He/She must be a citizen of India and not less than 21 years of age.
sections.content_md: Must be a citizen of India and at least **21 years of age**.

sections.title: (ii) He/She must be a registered voter, in the case of Panchayats, member of the Gram Sabha, in the constituency.
sections.content_md: Must be a registered voter in the constituency. For Panchayats, this means being a member of the **Gram Sabha**.

sections.title: (iii) He/She should not be a convict or have been disqualified by a Law of the Parliament or an undischarged insolvent.
sections.content_md: Should not be a convict, disqualified by law, or an undischarged insolvent.

sections.title: (iv) He/She should not hold any office of profit under the Government.
sections.content_md: Should not hold any **office of profit** under the Government.

sections.title: (b) Term:
sections.content_md: The **Constitution (73rd Amendment) Act, 1992** and **Part IX-A** (relating to Municipalities) provide for a uniform and fixed term of **5 years** for both rural and urban local bodies.

sections.title: GRAM PANCHAYAT
sections.content_md: The members of the **Gram Panchayat** are elected by the **Gram Sabha**. The Gram Sabha functions as the general body of the Gram Panchayat and consists of all adult men and women in the village who are registered as voters.

sections.title: COMPOSITION
sections.content_md: The composition of a Gram Panchayat is as follows:

sections.title: Sarpanch:
sections.content_md: The **Sarpanch** is the head of the Gram Panchayat. The method of election varies by state; some elect the Sarpanch directly, while others do so indirectly through the members of the Gram Panchayat. A **Vice-Sarpanch** is also elected from amongst the members.

sections.title: Members:
sections.content_md: The number of members is fixed by the State, typically ranging from **5 to 31**. In most states, a Village Panchayat has 5 to 9 members. **One-third of the seats** are reserved for women. Seats are also reserved for Scheduled Castes/Tribes in proportion to their population in the village. Members are elected based on the principle of **Adult Franchise**.

sections.title: Office Bearers:
sections.content_md: The **Sarpanch** and **Vice-Sarpanch** are honorary members and do not receive a salary. A paid **Secretary** and, for larger Panchayats, a **Treasurer** are appointed by the State government through district authorities.

sections.title: FUNCTIONS
sections.content_md: A Gram Panchayat performs various functions aimed at the decentralisation of political power.

sections.title: 1. Administrative Functions
sections.content_md: These are the primary public works and welfare functions of the Gram Panchayat.

sections.title: (i) All public works and public welfare functions like construction, repair and maintenance of village roads, cart tracks, bridges, drains, tanks and wells.
sections.content_md: Construction, repair, and maintenance of public infrastructure like village roads, bridges, drains, tanks, and wells.

sections.title: (ii) Upkeep of cremation and burial grounds.
sections.content_md: Maintenance of cremation and burial grounds.

sections.title: (iii) Sanitation, health, setting up of health centres and dispensaries.
sections.content_md: Ensuring sanitation and health, including the establishment of health centres and dispensaries.

sections.title: (iv) Providing primary education.
sections.content_md: Provision of primary education.

sections.title: (v) Arranging irrigation facilities, seeds, fertilisers.
sections.content_md: Arranging for agricultural necessities like irrigation facilities, seeds, and fertilisers.

sections.title: (vi) Registration of births and deaths.
sections.content_md: Registration of births and deaths in the village.

sections.title: (vii) Maintaining records of common village property, their sale and purchase and land grants.
sections.content_md: Maintaining records of common village property, including sales, purchases, and land grants.

sections.title: 2. Social and Economic Functions
sections.content_md: These functions are not obligatory and are performed based on the availability of funds.

sections.title: (i) Construction of guest houses, libraries, marriage halls, etc;
sections.content_md: Construction of community facilities like guest houses, libraries, and marriage halls.

sections.title: (ii) Organising regular village melas, fairs and exhibitions;
sections.content_md: Organising village fairs (*melas*), and exhibitions.

sections.title: (iii) Planting of trees, parks, gardens and playgrounds for recreation;
sections.content_md: Developing green spaces by planting trees and establishing parks, gardens, and playgrounds.

sections.title: (iv) Establishing fair price shops, Cooperative Credit Societies.
sections.content_md: Establishing fair price shops and Cooperative Credit Societies.

sections.title: 3. Judicial Functions
sections.content_md: These are discussed under Nyaya Panchayats.

sections.title: These are discussed under Nyaya Panchayats.
sections.content_md: The judicial functions at the village level are primarily handled by **Nyaya Panchayats**.

sections.title: NYAYA PANCHAYATS
sections.content_md:
**Nyaya Panchayat**, also called **Panchayati Adalat**, is set up for every three or four Gram Panchayats. These bodies exist in some States and perform judicial functions. Key characteristics include:

*   **(i)** They ensure quick and inexpensive justice for villagers.
*   **(ii)** They can impose a fine of up to Rs. 100.
*   **(iii)** They cannot award a sentence of imprisonment.
*   **(iv)** Lawyers are not allowed to appear before them.
*   **(v)** Generally, there is no appeal against their decision if powers are exercised within their jurisdiction.
*   **(vi)** However, under the Panchayats Act, Sub-divisional Magistrates and Sub-Judges of the District are empowered to hear appeals.
*   **(vii)** A person cannot simultaneously be a member of the Nyaya Panchayat and any other local self-governing body like the Gram Panchayat or Panchayat Samiti.
*   **(viii)** Their jurisdiction is decided by the state government or the State Judicial Service.

In this structure, the **Gram Sabha** acts as the General Body/legislature, the **Panchayat** as the Executive, and the **Nyaya Panchayat** as the Judicial Body for a village or group of villages.

sections.title: PANCHAYAT SAMITI (AT THE BLOCK LEVEL)
sections.content_md: This intermediate body at the block level is known by various names in different states, such as **Panchayat Samiti**, **Kshetra Samiti**, **Janapada Panchayat**, and **Panchayat Union Council**. The Community Block is essentially a Panchayat of the Panchayats.

sections.title: Composition:
sections.content_md: The Panchayat Samiti consists of representatives from Panchayats and other members:

sections.title: (i) Sarpanchs of all Panchayats concerned.
sections.content_md: Sarpanchs of all Panchayats within the block.

sections.title: (ii) Members of Legislative Assembly of the State from the area.
sections.content_md: Members of the State Legislative Assembly (MLAs) from that area.

sections.title: (iii) Members of Parliament belonging to the area.
sections.content_md: Members of Parliament (MPs) belonging to that area.

sections.title: (iv) Block Development Officers of the block or the area served by them.
sections.content_md: **Block Development Officers (BDOs)** of the block.

sections.title: (v) Co-opted members (provisional) representing women, Scheduled Castes/ Tribes.
sections.content_md: Co-opted members representing women and Scheduled Castes/Tribes.

sections.title: (vi) Representatives of Cooperative Societies (only in certain States).
sections.content_md:
Representatives of Cooperative Societies (in some states).

The Samiti also appoints various **Standing Committees** to undertake specialised works, which may include outside members.

sections.title: Office Bearers
sections.content_md: The key office bearers of the Panchayat Samiti are:

sections.title: Chairperson
sections.content_md: **Chairperson**: Elected from amongst its own members.

sections.title: Deputy Chairperson
sections.content_md: **Deputy Chairperson**: Elected from amongst its own members.

sections.title: Secretary
sections.content_md: **Secretary**: A salaried employee appointed by the State authorities through District Administration.

sections.title: FUNCTIONS
sections.content_md: The functions of the Panchayat Samiti include:

sections.title: (i) To supervise and coordinate the working of Gram Panchayats.
sections.content_md: To supervise and coordinate the functioning of the Gram Panchayats under its jurisdiction.

sections.title: (ii) To conduct higher education (higher secondary level and above) for a group of villages or at block level.
sections.content_md: To manage higher education (higher secondary level and above) at the block level.

sections.title: (iii) To provide hospital and health services with various facilities at community block level.
sections.content_md: To provide hospital and health services at the community block level.

sections.title: (iv) To pay special attention to development of agriculture through undertaking minor irrigation schemes, distribution of quality seeds and fertilisers.
sections.content_md: To promote agricultural development by undertaking minor irrigation projects and distributing quality seeds and fertilisers.

sections.title: (v) To approve building plans, undertake other development works including roads and bridges within the circle Panchayats.
sections.content_md: To approve building plans and carry out development works like roads and bridges within its Panchayats.

sections.title: (vi) To provide drinking water and execute other community development programmes.
sections.content_md: To provide drinking water and execute other community development programs.

sections.title: (vii) To act as a link between the Gram Panchayat and Zila Parishad.
sections.content_md: To serve as a link between the **Gram Panchayat** and the **Zila Parishad**.

sections.title: ZILA PARISHAD (AT DISTRICT LEVEL)
sections.content_md: The **Zila Parishad** is at the apex of the three-tier Panchayati Raj system. It is the local self-government unit at the district level. It links the State Government with the Gram Panchayats. The Zila Parishad is known by different names in various states, such as **District Development Council**, **Zila Parishad**, and **Mohkuma Parishad**.

sections.title: COMPOSITION
sections.content_md:
The membership of a Zila Parishad varies from **40 to 60** members and typically includes:
*   **Deputy Commissioner** of the District.
*   **Presidents** of all Panchayat Samitis in the district.
*   **Heads of all Government Departments** in the district.
*   **Members of Parliament (MPs)** and **Legislative Assembly (MLAs)** in the district (as Associate Members in some states).
*   A representative of each **cooperative society** (in some states).
*   Some **women** and **Scheduled Caste** members if not adequately represented.
*   **Co-opted members** with extraordinary experience and achievements in public service.

sections.title: Office Bearers
sections.content_md: The office bearers of the Zila Parishad are:

sections.title: Chairman:
sections.content_md: **Chairman**: Elected by members from amongst themselves, presides over meetings and conducts proceedings.

sections.title: Deputy Chairperson:
sections.content_md: **Deputy Chairperson**: Elected by members from amongst themselves.

sections.title: Secretary:
sections.content_md: **Secretary**: A whole-time paid employee of the state government.

sections.title: FUNCTIONS
sections.content_md: The Zila Parishad functions mostly through various **Standing Committees** and **District Boards**. Its functions vary from state to state but generally include the following:

sections.title: (i) Overseeing all-round development work of the district under the overall charge of an experienced functionary like the Deputy Commissioner.
sections.content_md: To oversee the all-round development of the district, usually under the charge of the **Deputy Commissioner**.

sections.title: (ii) The Standing Committees have each a Chairperson, and Deputy Chairperson, holds discussions and take decisions. Members of the District Boards are also included in the Standing Committee.
sections.content_md: To take decisions through its **Standing Committees**, which have their own Chairperson and Deputy Chairperson and include members of the District Boards.

sections.title: (iii) In practice, the Working Committee functions as the executive body of the District Board.
sections.content_md: The **Working Committee** often acts as the executive body of the District Board.

sections.title: (iv) Supervision of working of Panchayats is carried out.
sections.content_md: To supervise the working of Panchayats.

sections.title: (v) In some states like in Assam, Bihar and Punjab scrutiny of the budget estimates of Panchayat Samitis is done.
sections.content_md: In some states (e.g., Assam, Bihar, Punjab), it scrutinizes the budget estimates of the Panchayat Samitis.

sections.title: (vi) It cooperates with and coordinates the work of Panchayat Samitis for undertaking various development works specially minor irrigation works, vocational and industrial schools, village industries, sanitation and public health.
sections.content_md: To cooperate with and coordinate the work of Panchayat Samitis in development projects, including minor irrigation, vocational schools, village industries, sanitation, and public health.

sections.title: (vii) It advises the State Government on all matters relating to the Gram Panchayats and Panchayat Samitis under their own jurisdiction.
sections.content_md: To advise the State Government on all matters concerning the Gram Panchayats and Panchayat Samitis within its jurisdiction.

sections.title: ACHIEVEMENTS OF THE PANCHAYATI RAJ SYSTEM
sections.content_md:
The introduction of the three-tier Panchayati Raj system helped translate Gandhiji's dream of every village being a republic into reality. Key achievements include:

*   The **Ministry of Rural Development** provides training to Panchayat members to implement rural development schemes like **Swarnajayanti Gram Swarozgar Yojana (SGSY)**, bringing the government closer to the people.
*   **(a) Digitisation:** The Central government has initiated the process of digitising over 2.5 lakh Gram Panchayats. As part of the **Digital India program**, the **eGram Swaraj** portal was launched. This user-friendly, web-based portal aims to complete the digitisation of villages, maintain records of development activities, and make them accessible on mobile phones.
*   **(b) Coordination:** The system ensures effective coordination between government programs and those of voluntary agencies.
*   **(c) Rural Development Schemes:** The **District Rural Development Agencies (DRDAs)**, in cooperation with Zila Parishads, release funds to Gram Panchayats under schemes like the **Jawahar Gram Samridhi Yojana (JGSY)**, which aims to create demand-driven village infrastructure. The **Mahatma Gandhi National Rural Employment Guarantee Act (MGNREGA), 2005**, provides 100 days of unskilled manual work to every rural household, with the Gram Panchayat acting as the implementing agency.
